extension.name: org.apache.nifi.processors.mqtt.PublishMQTT
extension.description: Publishes a message to an MQTT topic

property.name: Broker URI
property.description: The URI to use to connect to the MQTT broker (e.g. tcp://localhost:1883). The 'tcp', 'ssl', 'ws' and 'wss' schemes are supported. In order to use 'ssl', the SSL Context Service property must be set.

property.name: Client ID
property.description: MQTT client ID to use. If not set, a UUID will be generated.

property.name: Username
property.description: Username to use when connecting to the broker

property.name: Password
property.description: Password to use when connecting to the broker

property.name: SSL Context Service
property.description: The SSL Context Service used to provide client certificate information for TLS/SSL connections.

property.name: Last Will Topic
property.description: The topic to send the client's Last Will to. If the Last Will topic and message are not set then a Last Will will not be sent.

property.name: Last Will Message
property.description: The message to send as the client's Last Will. If the Last Will topic and message are not set then a Last Will will not be sent.

property.name: Last Will Retain
property.description: Whether to retain the client's Last Will. If the Last Will topic and message are not set then a Last Will will not be sent.

property.name: Last Will QoS Level
property.description: QoS level to be used when publishing the Last Will Message

allowableValue.description: Best effort delivery. A message won’t be acknowledged by the receiver or stored and redelivered by the sender. This is often called “fire and forget” and provides the same guarantee as the underlying TCP protocol.
Guarantees that a message will be delivered at least once to the receiver. The message can also be delivered more than once

Guarantees that each message is received only once by the counterpart. It is the safest and also the slowest quality of service level. The guarantee is provided by two round-trip flows between sender and receiver.

property.name: Session state
property.description: Whether to start afresh or resume previous flows. See the allowable value descriptions for more details.

allowableValue.description: Client and Server discard any previous session and start a new one. This session lasts as long as the network connection. State data associated with this session is not reused in any subsequent session

Server resumes communications with the client based on state from the current session (as identified by the ClientID). The client and server store the session after the client and server are disconnected. After the disconnection of a session that was not a clean session, the server stores further QoS 1 and QoS 2 messages that match any subscriptions that the client had at the time of disconnection as part of the session state

property.name: MQTT Specification Version
property.description: The MQTT specification version when connecting with the broker. See the allowable value descriptions for more details.

allowableValue.description: Start with v3.1.1 and fallback to v3.1.0 if not supported by a broker

property.name: Connection Timeout (seconds)
property.description: Maximum time interval the client will wait for the network connection to the MQTT server to be established. The default timeout is 30 seconds. A value of 0 disables timeout processing meaning the client will wait until the network connection is made successfully or fails.

property.name: Keep Alive Interval (seconds)
property.description: Defines the maximum time interval between messages sent or received. It enables the client to detect if the server is no longer available, without having to wait for the TCP/IP timeout. The client will ensure that at least one message travels across the network within each keep alive period. In the absence of a data-related message during the time period, the client sends a very small "ping" message, which the server will acknowledge. A value of 0 disables keepalive processing in the client.

property.name: Topic
property.description: The topic to publish the message to.

property.name: Quality of Service(QoS)
property.description: The Quality of Service(QoS) to send the message with. Accepts three values '0', '1' and '2'; '0' for 'at most once', '1' for 'at least once', '2' for 'exactly once'. Expression language is allowed in order to support publishing messages with different QoS but the end value of the property must be either '0', '1' or '2'.

property.name: Retain Message
property.description: Whether or not the retain flag should be set on the MQTT message.

relationship.name: success
relationship.description: FlowFiles that are sent successfully to the destination are transferred to this relationship.

relationship.name: failure
relationship.description: FlowFiles that failed to send to the destination are transferred to this relationship.

systemResourceConsideration.description: An instance of this component can cause high usage of this system resource. Multiple instances or high concurrency settings may result a degradation of performance.

extension.name: org.apache.nifi.processors.mqtt.ConsumeMQTT
extension.description: Subscribes to a topic and receives messages from an MQTT broker

property.name: Broker URI
property.description: The URI to use to connect to the MQTT broker (e.g. tcp://localhost:1883). The 'tcp', 'ssl', 'ws' and 'wss' schemes are supported. In order to use 'ssl', the SSL Context Service property must be set.

property.name: Client ID
property.description: MQTT client ID to use. If not set, a UUID will be generated.

property.name: Username
property.description: Username to use when connecting to the broker

property.name: Password
property.description: Password to use when connecting to the broker

property.name: SSL Context Service
property.description: The SSL Context Service used to provide client certificate information for TLS/SSL connections.

property.name: Last Will Topic
property.description: The topic to send the client's Last Will to. If the Last Will topic and message are not set then a Last Will will not be sent.

property.name: Last Will Message
property.description: The message to send as the client's Last Will. If the Last Will topic and message are not set then a Last Will will not be sent.

property.name: Last Will Retain
property.description: Whether to retain the client's Last Will. If the Last Will topic and message are not set then a Last Will will not be sent.

property.name: Last Will QoS Level
property.description: QoS level to be used when publishing the Last Will Message

allowableValue.description: Best effort delivery. A message won’t be acknowledged by the receiver or stored and redelivered by the sender. This is often called “fire and forget” and provides the same guarantee as the underlying TCP protocol.
Guarantees that a message will be delivered at least once to the receiver. The message can also be delivered more than once

Guarantees that each message is received only once by the counterpart. It is the safest and also the slowest quality of service level. The guarantee is provided by two round-trip flows between sender and receiver.

property.name: Session state
property.description: Whether to start afresh or resume previous flows. See the allowable value descriptions for more details.

allowableValue.description: Client and Server discard any previous session and start a new one. This session lasts as long as the network connection. State data associated with this session is not reused in any subsequent session

Server resumes communications with the client based on state from the current session (as identified by the ClientID). The client and server store the session after the client and server are disconnected. After the disconnection of a session that was not a clean session, the server stores further QoS 1 and QoS 2 messages that match any subscriptions that the client had at the time of disconnection as part of the session state

property.name: MQTT Specification Version
property.description: The MQTT specification version when connecting with the broker. See the allowable value descriptions for more details.

allowableValue.description: Start with v3.1.1 and fallback to v3.1.0 if not supported by a broker

property.name: Connection Timeout (seconds)
property.description: Maximum time interval the client will wait for the network connection to the MQTT server to be established. The default timeout is 30 seconds. A value of 0 disables timeout processing meaning the client will wait until the network connection is made successfully or fails.

property.name: Keep Alive Interval (seconds)
property.description: Defines the maximum time interval between messages sent or received. It enables the client to detect if the server is no longer available, without having to wait for the TCP/IP timeout. The client will ensure that at least one message travels across the network within each keep alive period. In the absence of a data-related message during the time period, the client sends a very small "ping" message, which the server will acknowledge. A value of 0 disables keepalive processing in the client.

property.name: Group ID
property.description: MQTT consumer group ID to use. If group ID not set, client will connect as individual consumer.

property.name: Topic Filter
property.description: The MQTT topic filter to designate the topics to subscribe to.

property.name: Quality of Service(QoS)
property.description: The Quality of Service(QoS) to receive the message with. Accepts values '0', '1' or '2'; '0' for 'at most once', '1' for 'at least once', '2' for 'exactly once'.

allowableValue.description: Best effort delivery. A message won’t be acknowledged by the receiver or stored and redelivered by the sender. This is often called “fire and forget” and provides the same guarantee as the underlying TCP protocol.
Guarantees that a message will be delivered at least once to the receiver. The message can also be delivered more than once

Guarantees that each message is received only once by the counterpart. It is the safest and also the slowest quality of service level. The guarantee is provided by two round-trip flows between sender and receiver.

property.name: Max Queue Size
property.description: The MQTT messages are always being sent to subscribers on a topic. If the 'Run Schedule' is significantly behind the rate at which the messages are arriving to this processor then a back up can occur. This property specifies the maximum number of messages this processor will hold in memory at one time.

writesAttribute.name: mqtt.broker
writesAttribute.description: MQTT broker that was the message source

writesAttribute.name: mqtt.topic
writesAttribute.description: MQTT topic on which message was received

writesAttribute.name: mqtt.qos
writesAttribute.description: The quality of service for this message.

writesAttribute.name: mqtt.isDuplicate
writesAttribute.description: Whether or not this message might be a duplicate of one which has already been received.

writesAttribute.name: mqtt.isRetained
writesAttribute.description: Whether or not this message was from a current publisher, or was "retained" by the server as the last message published on the topic.
